name: Physiology
content: Updating pysiology in page-edit - updating with pageid =8 and again
contents1:
Proximal to distal:

  • Conducting zone
  • Trachea
  • Bronchi
  • Bronchioles
  • Terminal bronchioles = have SM, collapse with forced expiration/coughing, see closing capacity
  • Respiratory zone (distal 7 generations)
  • Respiratory bronchioles
  • Alveolar ducts
  • Alveolar sacs

Approximately 23 generations

With increasing lung volume, radial traction = increased conducting zone diameter = decreased airway resistance

Gas exchange occurs within respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts, and alveoli

Surface area of alveoli is approx 50-100m2
question2: Draw a spirometry trace with lung volumes/values included.  What determines FRC, what increases/decreases?
contents2:
TLC : 6000ml

VC (vital capacity) : 4800L

TV : Tidal volume 400-600ml

IRV : Inspiratory reserve volume 2500ml

ERV Expiratory reserve volume 1200ml

RV: Residual volume 1200-1500L

FRC functional residual capacity : 3000ml standing or 2000ml supine

 

FRC is dependent on the balance of the tendency of the lungs to recoil and the thoracic cage to expand.

Under conditions of apnoea, FRC represents the pulmonary oxygen store.

 

If FRC is 2500 mL, breathing 21% O2 the oxygen store is 500 mL, but this can be increased by preoxygenation (denitrogenation) to 2500 mL.

If resting total body O2 requirement is 250 mL/min, FRC represents a 10 minute O2 store during apnoea.

  • > FRC is increased by:
  • Standing position
  • COPD
  • Asthma
  • PEEP.
  • > FRC is reduced by:
  • Supine position
  • General anaesthesia
  • Pregnancy
  • Obesity.

 

The closing capacity is the volume of the lungs at which the small airways begin to collapse and close off.
contents3:
Intrapleural pressure

Negative (sub-atmospheric) throughout normal breathing at rest - balance between lung and chest recoil

-5cmH2O at end expiration

-8cmH2O during inspiration

Pressure at apex is more negative to support weight of lung

Becomes more negative during inspiration

Is positive during Valsalva manoeuvre

Can be assessed via measurement of oesophageal pressure
question4: Which lung volumes can be measured with a spirometer? How can absolute lung volumes(capacities) be measured?
contents4:
Any lung volume that incorporates residual volume cannot be measured with simple spirometry (i.e. TLC, RV and FRC), the rest can be measured:

 

How can absolute lung volumes be measured?

  • anything with RV included: ie, TLC, VC, and FRC
  • These cannot be measured by simple spirometry, but require the use of more advanced techniques such as:
  • gas dilution or body plethysmography
  • Nitrogen wash-out
  • same method as for Helium wash-in :
  • FxN2(bag) x VB(bag) = (FLN2 - FxN2) x VL (lung)
  • Helium wash-in
  • Exactly the same principle is used for the helium wash-in method of determining RV or FRC.
  • Both the nitrogen washout and helium wash-in methods measure only communicating gas.
  • This is a disadvantage compared to the total body plethysmography method, which is able to measure communicating and non-communicating gas (i.e. gas trapped behind closed airways).

A body plethysmograph

  • Large box used to measure lung volumes and pressure; used to measure:
  • Residual volume + TLC
  • Airways resistance - dependent on flow
  • Lung compliance
  • Work of breathing
  • Pulmonary blood flow
  • Relies on Boyle’s law
  • Measures gas that may be missed with the helium dilution technique in diseased lungs
